paragraphs.text: Where Afghan law fails women.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: Afghan women have come a long way since the dark days of the Taliban regime
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Yet a key obstacle to this progress continues to be high levels of violence against women
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The legal system has failed to protect women adequately when it comes to some of the most common crimes against them; rape, domestic violence, underage and forced marriages
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That is why, in 2009, a number of prominent Afghan women's rights activists, members of civil society groups, and some lawmakers came together to draft a bill to better protect women through legal channels and to define crimes of violence against women
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The bill, known as The Elimination of Violence Against Women (EVAW) Law, was decreed into law through an Executive Order by the former Afghan President Hamid Karzaion, on July 20, 2009, while parliament was in recess
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: During such periods, the Afghan Constitution allows the president to issue decrees for emergency purposes
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the Constitution also requires such decrees to be forwarded to parliament for approval
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: Some women activists nonetheless suggested that it was not necessary to send the EVAW law to parliament
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Political climate
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Others, including myself, argued that although the Executive Order on EVAW was a significant step in the battle for the elimination of violence against women, the law remained vulnerable to being reversed by a new president
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Indeed
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: presidential elections were just around the corner
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: As the drawdown of the international troops drew nearer, we feared that the political climate would make it increasingly difficult to get the law anchored in parliament
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In addition
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: we feared that any peace talks with the Taliban could end up sacrificing EVAW in a bid to appease the militants
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Securing parliamentary approval for the law would give us much stronger ammunition in protecting it against extremist attacks
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In order to get an agreement on the EVAW law in parliament, we worked tirelessly for months, using three main strategies
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Firstly, we started a lobbying campaign with those who opposed the law, mainly conservatives
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Secondly, we went to visit them in their houses, explaining the law to them article by article to obtain their signature in support of the law
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: We also organised exchange visits for conservative MPs to other Muslim countries so they could explore how these countries had been enforcing similar legislation for decades
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Finally we worked through the joint committee in parliament for more than two years to develop a consensus on the law and defuse the opposition of conservatives
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In late 2009, there were only two issues left where conservative MPs did not agree
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: These were the law's punishment of relatives for underage marriage and for polygamy under certain conditions as well as the fact that women's rights advocates wanted to include "honour killings" as a specific crime in the law
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: At this point, however, MPs became increasingly preoccupied with the then- upcoming parliamentary elections scheduled for Spring 2010
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: thus
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the process lost momentum
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Unfortunately, after the 2010 parliamentary elections, we ended up with a more conservative parliament
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Contested election results left the new parliament paralysed for almost a year
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: As a consequence, discussions about the EVAW law only resumed in mid-2011
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: At this time the draft was re-sent to the 18 parliamentary commissions
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: All but one of the commissions agreed with the text of the law or presented constructive suggestions
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The final commission, the legislative (Taqnin) committee, headed by the foremost opponent of the EVAW law, submitted 34 pages of suggested amendments
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Some of these suggestions were helpful and were duly included, such as a proposal to have specialised prosecution units in all of Afghanistan
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As before, we rejected the proposals to leave underage marriage and the contraction of invalid polygamous marriages as non-punishable acts
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: We similarly rejected a new suggestion
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: which was to close all women's shelters and arrange for the victims of violence to stay with relatives instead
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Although the opponents were vocal
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: they did not outnumber the rest
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: What was damaging, however, was an unhealthy political rivalry that ensued among mostly female parliamentarians and supporters of EVAW
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Some progressive women's rights activists, including some from international organisations, argued that the time was not right to pass the EVAW and that it should be left as a presidential decree
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: There were good reasons for seeking parliamentary approval
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Yet some of my colleagues began accusing me of using the bill to further my own political career and gain support for my assumed ambitions for the 2014 presidential elections
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Instead of supporting EVAW, many female MPs stood silent during the parliamentary debates on the bill
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: some even went as far as to lobby against it
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: As a result, when the law was presented to the plenary in May 2013, conservative MPs who were opposed to EVAW were further emboldened
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The new Speaker of the House did not hold a lot a lot of influence
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: probably, for that reason, did not back the bill either
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: With the conservative MPs entrenched in their opposition to EVAW, a weak speaker and a lack of support from my fellow female MPs, the EVAW bill failed to pass
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Those of us who saw the passing of EVAW to be beyond politics, and understood its importance for tackling violence against women, were left heartbroken
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: With the international community now gradually disengaging from Afghanistan, time is running out for Afghan women
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We have made important gains since 2001
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: we need the force of the law behind us to sustain our achievements
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We need to arm ourselves with solid laws like the EVAW law to fight the violence and other ills of our society
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which are destroying the souls of our sisters across the country
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The fact that the EVAW law has not been approved by the parliament is the reason for its weak implementation rates
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: many justice officials are questioning the law's status and therefore do not apply it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: One promising thing on the horizon is that we now have a president and chief executive who both understand the multitude of challenges facing women
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I would like to take this opportunity and call on President Ashraf Ghani and our Chief Executive Dr Abdullah Abdullah to declare their support for the passage of the EVAW bill
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I also call on my female colleagues in parliament and all Afghan women rights activists and our international partners to set aside their differences and join us in support of the ratification of the bill
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As the recent parliamentary approval of the BSA shows, when the government and others make something a priority, the conservative MPs can be isolated
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Times may be difficult now for Afghanistan
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: differences may be wide
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: security challenges are growing
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: failure to back the EVAW and allowing it to die will deal a severe blow to Afghan women's rights
paragraphs.label: assumption
